title: Learning Objective: 02-01 Explain the concept of sufficiency of a good tax.

stem:
Country M levies a {{[a(1)]:#,###}} percent excise tax on the retail price of any automobile purchased in the country. This year, the aggregate purchase price subject to tax was ${{[a(2)]:#,##0.0}} million, so current year revenue was ${{[a(3)]:#,###}}. Country M plans to increase the tax rate next year to {{[a(4)]:#,###}} percent.
 

  1. Compute next year’s excise tax revenue assuming next year’s tax base equals the current year base.
  2. Compute next year’s excise tax revenue assuming next year’s tax base increases to ${{[a(5)]:#,###.0}} million.
  3. Compute next year’s excise tax revenue assuming next year’s tax base decreases to ${{[a(6)]:#,###.0}} million.


__ans__
commonFeedback:
1. Next year’s excise tax revenue will be ${{[a(7)]:#,###}} (${{[a(2)]:#,##0.0}} million base × 11%).
  2. Next year’s excise tax revenue will be ${{[a(8)]:#,###}} (${{[a(5)]:#,##0.0}} million base × 11%).
  3. Next year’s excise tax revenue will be ${{[a(9)]:#,###}} (${{[a(6)]:#,##0.0}} million base × 11%).

title: Learning Objective: 02-01 Explain the concept of sufficiency of a good tax.

stem:
Country M levies a 10 percent excise tax on the retail price of any automobile purchased in the country. This year, the aggregate purchase price subject to tax was $8 million, so current year revenue was $800,000. Country M plans to increase the tax rate next year to 11 percent.
 

  1. Compute next year’s excise tax revenue assuming next year’s tax base equals the current year base.
  2. Compute next year’s excise tax revenue assuming next year’s tax base increases to $9.3 million.
  3. Compute next year’s excise tax revenue assuming next year’s tax base decreases to $7 million.


__ans__
commonFeedback:
1. Next year’s excise tax revenue will be $880,000 ($8 million base × 11%).
  2. Next year’s excise tax revenue will be $1,023,000 ($9.3 million base × 11%).
  3. Next year’s excise tax revenue will be $770,000 ($7 million base × 11%).

title: Learning Objective: 02-01 Explain the concept of sufficiency of a good tax.

stem:
The city of Lakeland levies a {{[a(1)]:#,###}} percent tax on the value of all restaurant meals served to the public within the city limits. This year, the aggregate value subject to tax was ${{[a(2)]:#,###.0}} million, so current year revenue was ${{[a(3)]:#,###}}. Lakeland plans to decrease the tax rate next year to {{[a(4)]:#,###.0}} percent.
 

  1. Compute next year’s restaurant tax revenue assuming next year’s tax base equals the current year base.
  2. Compute next year’s restaurant tax revenue assuming next year’s tax base increases to ${{[a(5)]:#,###.0}} million.
  3. Compute next year’s restaurant tax revenue assuming next year’s tax base increases to ${{[a(6)]:#,###.0}} million.


__ans__
commonFeedback:
1. Next year’s restaurant tax revenue will be ${{[a(7)]:#,###}} (${{[a(2)]:#,###.0}} million base × {{[a(4)]:#,###.0}}%).
  2. Next year’s restaurant tax revenue will be ${{[a(8)]:#,###}} (${{[a(5)]:#,###.0}} million base × {{[a(4)]:#,###.0}}%).
  3. Next year’s restaurant tax revenue will be ${{[a(9)]:#,###}} (${{[a(6)]:#,###.0}} million base × {{[a(4)]:#,###.0}}%).

title: Learning Objective: 02-01 Explain the concept of sufficiency of a good tax.

stem:
The city of Lakeland levies a 2 percent tax on the value of all restaurant meals served to the public within the city limits. This year, the aggregate value subject to tax was $29.4 million, so current year revenue was $588,000. Lakeland plans to decrease the tax rate next year to 1.5 percent.
 

  1. Compute next year’s restaurant tax revenue assuming next year’s tax base equals the current year base.
  2. Compute next year’s restaurant tax revenue assuming next year’s tax base increases to $36 million.
  3. Compute next year’s restaurant tax revenue assuming next year’s tax base increases to $41 million.

__ans__
commonFeedback:
1. Next year’s restaurant tax revenue will be $441,000 ($29.4 million base × 1.5%).
  2. Next year’s restaurant tax revenue will be $540,000 ($36 million base × 1.5%).
  3. Next year’s restaurant tax revenue will be $615,000 ($41 million base × 1.5%).

title: Learning Objective: 02-01 Explain the concept of sufficiency of a good tax.

stem:
The city of Clement levies a {{[a(1)]:#,###}} percent tax on the base price of rooms provided by hotels and motels located within the city limits. This year, the aggregate room price subject to tax was ${{[a(2)]:#,###}} million, so current year revenue was ${{[a(3)]:#,##0.00}} million. Clement’s city council recently voted to increase the hotel tax rate to {{[a(4)]:#,###}} percent for the next fiscal year.
 

  1. Compute next year’s hotel tax revenue assuming next year’s tax base equals the current year base.
  2. Compute next year’s hotel tax revenue assuming next year’s tax base decreases to ${{[a(5)]:#,###}} million.
  3. Compute next year’s hotel tax revenue assuming next year’s tax base decreases to ${{[a(6)]:#,###}} million.


__ans__
commonFeedback:
1. Next year’s hotel tax revenue will be ${{[a(7)]:#,##0.00}} million (${{[a(2)]:#,###}} million base × {{[a(4)]:#,###}}%).
  2. Next year’s hotel tax revenue will be ${{[a(8)]:#,##0.00}} million (${{[a(5)]:#,###}} million base × {{[a(4)]:#,###}}%).
  3. Next year’s hotel tax revenue will be ${{[a(9)]:#,##0.00}} million (${{[a(6)]:#,###}} million base × {{[a(4)]:#,###}}%).

title: Learning Objective: 02-01 Explain the concept of sufficiency of a good tax.

stem:
The city of Clement levies a 5 percent tax on the base price of rooms provided by hotels and motels located within the city limits. This year, the aggregate room price subject to tax was $25 million, so current year revenue was $1.25 million. Clement’s city council recently voted to increase the hotel tax rate to 6 percent for the next fiscal year.
 

  1. Compute next year’s hotel tax revenue assuming next year’s tax base equals the current year base.
  2. Compute next year’s hotel tax revenue assuming next year’s tax base decreases to $22 million.
  3. Compute next year’s hotel tax revenue assuming next year’s tax base decreases to $19 million.


__ans__
commonFeedback:
1. Next year’s hotel tax revenue will be $1.50 million ($25 million base × 6%).
  2. Next year’s hotel tax revenue will be $1.32 million ($22 million base × 6%).
  3. Next year’s hotel tax revenue will be $1.14 million ($19 million base × 6%).

title: Learning Objective: 02-01 Explain the concept of sufficiency of a good tax.
Learning Objective: 02-02 Differentiate between the income effect and the substitution effect.
Topic: Behavioral Responses to Rate Changes

stem:
Mrs. King, a single taxpayer, earns a ${{[a(1)]:#,###}} annual salary and pays {{[a(2)]:#,###}} percent in state and federal income tax. If tax rates increase so that Mrs. King’s annual tax rate is {{[a(3)]:#,###}} percent, how much additional income must she earn to maintain her after-tax disposable income?

__new__
commonFeedback:
Before the rate increase, Mrs. King’s disposable income is ${{[a(10)]:#,###}} (${{[a(1)]:#,###}} − ${{[a(4)]:#,###}} tax). If the tax rate increases from {{[a(2)]:#,###}} percent to {{[a(3)]:#,###}} percent, she must earn an additional ${{[a(6)]:#,###}} to maintain this income. This number is derived from the following formula.

(${{[a(1)]:#,###}} + additional income) − {{[a(3)]:#,###}}% (${{[a(1)]:#,###}} + additional income) = ${{[a(10)]:#,###}}

If Mrs. King can earn an extra ${{[a(6)]:#,###}}, her disposable income won’t be affected by the rate increase.

       
Taxable income $ {{[a(7)]:#,###}}  
Tax rate   {{[a(8)]:#,##0.00}}  
Tax $ {{[a(9)]:#,###}}  


After-tax income (${{[a(7)]:#,###}} − ${{[a(9)]:#,###}}) = ${{[a(10)]:#,###}}

title: Learning Objective: 02-01 Explain the concept of sufficiency of a good tax.
Learning Objective: 02-02 Differentiate between the income effect and the substitution effect.
Topic: Behavioral Responses to Rate Changes

stem:
Mrs. King, a single taxpayer, earns a $42,000 annual salary and pays 15 percent in state and federal income tax. If tax rates increase so that Mrs. King’s annual tax rate is 20 percent, how much additional income must she earn to maintain her after-tax disposable income?

__new__
commonFeedback:
Before the rate increase, Mrs. King’s disposable income is $35,700 ($42,000 − $6,300 tax). If the tax rate increases from 15 percent to 20 percent, she must earn an additional $2,625 to maintain this income. This number is derived from the following formula.

($42,000 + additional income) − 20% ($42,000 + additional income) = $35,700

If Mrs. King can earn an extra $2,625, her disposable income won’t be affected by the rate increase.

       
Taxable income $ 44,625  
Tax rate   0.20  
Tax $ 8,925  


After-tax income ($44,625 − $8,925) = $35,700

title: Learning Objective: 02-02 Differentiate between the income effect and the substitution effect.
Topic: Behavioral Responses to Rate Changes

stem:
Mr. Esposito, a petroleum engineer, earns an ${{[a(1)]:#,###}} annual salary, while Mrs. Esposito, a homemaker, has no earned income. Under current law, the couple pays {{[a(2)]:#,###}} percent in state and federal income tax. Because of recent tax law changes, the couple’s future tax rate will increase to {{[a(3)]:#,###}} percent. If Mrs. Esposito decides to take a part-time job because of the rate increase, how much income must she earn to maintain the couple’s after-tax disposable income? (Round your intermediate calculations and final answer to the nearest whole dollar amount.)

__new__
commonFeedback:
Before the rate increase, Mr. and Mrs. Esposito’s disposable income is ${{[a(10)]:#,###}} (${{[a(1)]:#,###}} − ${{[a(4)]:#,###}} tax). If the tax rate increases from {{[a(2)]:#,###}} percent to {{[a(3)]:#,###}} percent, Mrs. Esposito must earn an additional ${{[a(6)]:#,###}} to maintain this income. This number is derived from the following formula.

(${{[a(1)]:#,###}} + additional income) − {{[a(3)]:#,###}}% (${{[a(1)]:#,###}} + additional income) = ${{[a(10)]:#,###}}

If Mrs. Esposito can earn ${{[a(6)]:#,###}} from her part-time job, the couple’s disposable income won’t be affected by the rate increase.

       
Taxable income $ {{[a(7)]:#,###}}  
Tax rate   {{[a(8)]:#,##0.00}}  
Tax $ {{[a(9)]:#,###}}  


After-tax income (${{[a(7)]:#,###}} − ${{[a(9)]:#,###}}) = ${{[a(10)]:#,###}}

title: Learning Objective: 02-02 Differentiate between the income effect and the substitution effect.
Topic: Behavioral Responses to Rate Changes

stem:
Mr. Esposito, a petroleum engineer, earns an $83,000 annual salary, while Mrs. Esposito, a homemaker, has no earned income. Under current law, the couple pays 20 percent in state and federal income tax. Because of recent tax law changes, the couple’s future tax rate will increase to 28 percent. If Mrs. Esposito decides to take a part-time job because of the rate increase, how much income must she earn to maintain the couple’s after-tax disposable income? (Round your intermediate calculations and final answer to the nearest whole dollar amount.)

__new__
commonFeedback:
Before the rate increase, Mr. and Mrs. Esposito’s disposable income is $66,400 ($83,000 − $16,600 tax). If the tax rate increases from 20 percent to 28 percent, Mrs. Esposito must earn an additional $9,222 to maintain this income. This number is derived from the following formula.

($83,000 + additional income) − 28% ($83,000 + additional income) = $66,400

If Mrs. Esposito can earn $9,222 from her part-time job, the couple’s disposable income won’t be affected by the rate increase.

       
Taxable income $ 92,222  
Tax rate   0.28  
Tax $ 25,822  


After-tax income ($92,222 − $25,822) = $66,400

title: Learning Objective: 02-02 Differentiate between the income effect and the substitution effect.
Topic: Behavioral Responses to Rate Changes

stem:
Mr. and Mrs. Jerald own a dry cleaning business that generates ${{[a(1)]:#,###}} taxable income each year. For the past few years, the couple’s federal tax rate on this income has been {{[a(2)]:#,###}} percent. Congress recently increased the tax rate for next year to {{[a(3)]:#,###}} percent.

  1. Based on a static forecast, how much additional revenue will the federal government collect from Mr. and Mrs. Jerald next year?
  2. How much additional revenue will the government collect if Mr. and Mrs. Jerald respond to the rate increase by working harder and earning ${{[a(4)]:#,###}} next year?
  3. How much additional revenue will the government collect if Mr. and Mrs. Jerald respond to the rate increase by working less and earning only ${{[a(5)]:#,###}} next year?


__ans__
commonFeedback:
a.

${{[a(1)]:#,###}} tax base (Mr. and Mrs. Jerald’s taxable income) × {{[a(6)]:#,###}}% rate increase = ${{[a(7)]:#,###}} additional revenue collected from Mr. and Mrs. Jerald.

b.

           
  ${{[a(4)]:#,###}} increased tax base × {{[a(3)]:#,###}}% $ {{[a(8)]:#,###}}    
  Tax collected on original ${{[a(1)]:#,###}} base × {{[a(2)]:#,###}}%   ({{[a(9)]:#,###}} )  
  Additional revenue collected from Mr. and Mrs. Jerald $ {{[a(10)]:#,###}}    


c.

           
  ${{[a(5)]:#,###}} decreased tax base × {{[a(3)]:#,###}}% $ {{[a(11)]:#,###}}    
  Tax collected on original ${{[a(1)]:#,###}} base × {{[a(2)]:#,###}}%   ({{[a(9)]:#,###}} )  
  Additional revenue collected from Mr. and Mrs. Jerald $ {{[a(12)]:#,###}}

title: Learning Objective: 02-02 Differentiate between the income effect and the substitution effect.
Topic: Behavioral Responses to Rate Changes

stem:
Mr. and Mrs. Jerald own a dry cleaning business that generates $125,000 taxable income each year. For the past few years, the couple’s federal tax rate on this income has been 32 percent. Congress recently increased the tax rate for next year to 40 percent.

  1. Based on a static forecast, how much additional revenue will the federal government collect from Mr. and Mrs. Jerald next year?
  2. How much additional revenue will the government collect if Mr. and Mrs. Jerald respond to the rate increase by working harder and earning $140,000 next year?
  3. How much additional revenue will the government collect if Mr. and Mrs. Jerald respond to the rate increase by working less and earning only $110,000 next year?


__ans__
commonFeedback:
a.

$125,000 tax base (Mr. and Mrs. Jerald’s taxable income) × 8% rate increase = $10,000 additional revenue collected from Mr. and Mrs. Jerald.


b.

         
$140,000 increased tax base × 40% $ 56,000    
Tax collected on original $125,000 base × 32%   (40,000 )  
Additional revenue collected from Mr. and Mrs. Jerald $ 16,000    


c.

         
$110,000 decreased tax base × 40% $ 44,000    
Tax collected on original $125,000 base × 32%   (40,000 )  
Additional revenue collected from Mr. and Mrs. Jerald $ 4,000

title: Learning Objective: 02-02 Differentiate between the income effect and the substitution effect.
Topic: Behavioral Responses to Rate Changes

stem:
Ms. Benoit is a self-employed architect who earns ${{[a(1)]:#,###}} annual taxable income. For the past several years, her tax rate on this income has been {{[a(2)]:#,###}} percent. Because of recent tax law changes, Ms. Benoit’s tax rate for next year will decrease to {{[a(3)]:#,###}} percent.

  1. Based on a static forecast, how much less revenue will the government collect from Ms. Benoit next year?
  2. How much less revenue will the government collect from Ms. Benoit next year if she responds to the rate decrease by working more hours and earning ${{[a(4)]:#,###}} taxable income?
  3. How much less revenue will the government collect from Ms. Benoit next year if she responds to the rate decrease by working fewer hours and earning only ${{[a(5)]:#,###}} taxable income?


__ans__
commonFeedback:
a.

${{[a(1)]:#,###}} tax base (Ms. Benoit’s taxable income) × {{[a(6)]:#,###}}% rate decrease = ${{[a(7)]:#,###}} decrease in revenue collected from Ms. Benoit.
 

b.

         
${{[a(4)]:#,###}} increased tax base × {{[a(3)]:#,###}}% $ {{[a(8)]:#,###}}    
Tax collected on original ${{[a(1)]:#,###}} base × {{[a(2)]:#,###}}%   ({{[a(9)]:#,###}} )  
Decrease in revenue collected from Ms. Benoit $ ({{[a(10)]:#,###}} )  


c.

         
${{[a(5)]:#,###}} decreased tax base × {{[a(3)]:#,###}}% $ {{[a(11)]:#,###}}    
Tax collected on original ${{[a(1)]:#,###}} base × {{[a(2)]:#,###}}%   ({{[a(9)]:#,###}} )  
Decrease in revenue collected from Ms. Benoit $ ({{[a(12)]:#,###}} )

title: Learning Objective: 02-02 Differentiate between the income effect and the substitution effect.
Topic: Behavioral Responses to Rate Changes

stem:
Ms. Benoit is a self-employed architect who earns $300,000 annual taxable income. For the past several years, her tax rate on this income has been 35 percent. Because of recent tax law changes, Ms. Benoit’s tax rate for next year will decrease to 25 percent.
 

  1. Based on a static forecast, how much less revenue will the government collect from Ms. Benoit next year?
  2. How much less revenue will the government collect from Ms. Benoit next year if she responds to the rate decrease by working more hours and earning $375,000 taxable income?
  3. How much less revenue will the government collect from Ms. Benoit next year if she responds to the rate decrease by working fewer hours and earning only $275,000 taxable income?


__ans__
commonFeedback:
a.

$300,000 tax base (Ms. Benoit’s taxable income) × 10% rate decrease = $30,000 decrease in revenue collected from Ms. Benoit.

b.

         
$375,000 increased tax base × 25% $ 93,750    
Tax collected on original $300,000 base × 35%   (105,000 )  
Decrease in revenue collected from Ms. Benoit $ (11,250 )  


c.

         
$275,000 decreased tax base × 25% $ 68,750    
Tax collected on original $300,000 base × 35%   (105,000 )  
Decrease in revenue collected from Ms. Benoit $ (36,250 )

title: Learning Objective: 02-06 Differentiate between regressive, proportionate, and progressive rate structures.
Learning Objective: 02-07 Explain the difference between marginal and average tax rates.
Topic: Marginal and Average Tax Rates

stem:
Jurisdiction B levies a flat {{[a(1)]:#,###}} percent tax on the first ${{[a(2)]:#,###}} million of annual corporate income.
 

  1. Jersey Inc. generated ${{[a(3)]:#,###.0}} million income this year. Compute Jersey’s income tax and determine its average and marginal tax rate on total income.
  2. Leray Inc. generated ${{[a(4)]:#,###.0}} million income this year. Compute Leray’s income tax and determine Leray’s average and marginal tax rate on total income.
  3. What type of rate structure does Jurisdiction B use for its corporate income tax?


__ans__
commonFeedback:
1. Jersey Inc.’s income tax is ${{[a(5)]:#,###}} (${{[a(3)]:#,###.0}} million × {{[a(1)]:#,###}}%), and its average and marginal tax rates are {{[a(1)]:#,###}}%.
  2. Leray Inc.’s income tax is ${{[a(6)]:#,###}} (${{[a(2)]:#,###}} million × {{[a(1)]:#,###}}%). Its average rate is {{[a(7)]:#,###.0}}% (${{[a(6)]:#,###}} ÷ ${{[a(4)]:#,###.0}} million), and its marginal rate is 0%.
  3. Jurisdiction B uses a regressive rate structure because the average rate decreases as the tax base (corporate income) increases.

title: Learning Objective: 02-06 Differentiate between regressive, proportionate, and progressive rate structures.
Learning Objective: 02-07 Explain the difference between marginal and average tax rates.
Topic: Marginal and Average Tax Rates

stem:
Jurisdiction B levies a flat 7 percent tax on the first $5 million of annual corporate income.
 

  1. Jersey Inc. generated $3.9 million income this year. Compute Jersey’s income tax and determine its average and marginal tax rate on total income.
  2. Leray Inc. generated $9.6 million income this year. Compute Leray’s income tax and determine Leray’s average and marginal tax rate on total income.
  3. What type of rate structure does Jurisdiction B use for its corporate income tax?


__ans__
commonFeedback:
1. Jersey Inc.’s income tax is $273,000 ($3.9 million × 7%), and its average and marginal tax rates are 7%.
  2. Leray Inc.’s income tax is $350,000 ($5 million × 7%). Its average rate is 3.6% ($350,000 ÷ $9.6 million), and its marginal rate is 0%.
  3. Jurisdiction B uses a regressive rate structure because the average rate decreases as the tax base (corporate income) increases.

title: Learning Objective: 02-06 Differentiate between regressive, proportionate, and progressive rate structures.
Learning Objective: 02-07 Explain the difference between marginal and average tax rates.
Topic: Marginal and Average Tax Rates

stem:
Jurisdiction X levies a flat {{[a(1)]:#,###}} percent tax on individual income in excess of ${{[a(2)]:#,###}} per year. Individuals who earn ${{[a(2)]:#,###}} or less pay no income tax.
 

  1. Mr. Hill earned ${{[a(3)]:#,###}} income this year. Compute his income tax and determine his average and marginal tax rate.
  2. Ms. Lui earned ${{[a(4)]:#,###}} income this year. Compute her income tax and determine her average and marginal tax rate.
  3. Ms. Archer earned ${{[a(5)]:#,###}} income this year and paid no income tax. Describe her average and marginal tax rate.
  4. What type of rate structure does Jurisdiction X use for its individual income tax?


__ans__
commonFeedback:
1. Mr. Hill’s taxable income is ${{[a(6)]:#,###}} (${{[a(3)]:#,###}} − ${{[a(2)]:#,###}}), and his tax is ${{[a(7)]:#,###}} (${{[a(6)]:#,###}} × {{[a(1)]:#,###}}%). His average rate is {{[a(8)]:#,###.0}}% (${{[a(7)]:#,###}} ÷ ${{[a(3)]:#,###}}), and his marginal rate is {{[a(1)]:#,###}}%.
  2. Ms. Lui’s taxable income is ${{[a(9)]:#,###}} (${{[a(4)]:#,###}} − ${{[a(2)]:#,###}}), and her tax is ${{[a(10)]:#,###}} (${{[a(9)]:#,###}} × {{[a(1)]:#,###}}%). Her average rate is {{[a(11)]:#,##0.0}}% (${{[a(10)]:#,###}} ÷ ${{[a(4)]:#,###}}), and her marginal tax rate is {{[a(1)]:#,###}}%.
  3. Ms. Archer’s average and marginal rates are zero.
  4. Jurisdiction X uses a progressive rate structure, because the average rate increases as the tax base (individual income) increases.

title: Learning Objective: 02-06 Differentiate between regressive, proportionate, and progressive rate structures.
Learning Objective: 02-07 Explain the difference between marginal and average tax rates.
Topic: Marginal and Average Tax Rates

stem:
Jurisdiction X levies a flat 14 percent tax on individual income in excess of $35,000 per year. Individuals who earn $35,000 or less pay no income tax.
 

  1. Mr. Hill earned $98,750 income this year. Compute his income tax and determine his average and marginal tax rate.
  2. Ms. Lui earned $47,900 income this year. Compute her income tax and determine her average and marginal tax rate.
  3. Ms. Archer earned $34,100 income this year and paid no income tax. Describe her average and marginal tax rate.
  4. What type of rate structure does Jurisdiction X use for its individual income tax?


__ans__
commonFeedback:
1. Mr. Hill’s taxable income is $63,750 ($98,750 − $35,000), and his tax is $8,925 ($63,750 × 14%). His average rate is 9.0% ($8,925 ÷ $98,750), and his marginal rate is 14%.
  2. Ms. Lui’s taxable income is $12,900 ($47,900 − $35,000), and her tax is $1,806 ($12,900 × 14%). Her average rate is 3.8% ($1,806 ÷ $47,900), and her marginal tax rate is 14%.
  3. Ms. Archer’s average and marginal rates are zero.
  4. Jurisdiction X uses a progressive rate structure, because the average rate increases as the tax base (individual income) increases.

title: Learning Objective: 02-07 Explain the difference between marginal and average tax rates.
Topic: Marginal and Average Tax Rates

stem:
Government G levies an income tax with the following rate structure:
 

Percentage Rate Bracket
  6 % Income from –0– to $30,000
  10   Income from $30,001 to $70,000
  20   Income from $70,001 to $200,000
  28   Income in excess of $200,000
 
  1. Taxpayer A’s taxable income is ${{[a(9)]:#,###}}. Compute A’s tax and average tax rate. What is A’s marginal tax rate?
  2. Taxpayer B’s taxable income is ${{[a(10)]:#,###}}. Compute B’s tax and average tax rate. What is B’s marginal tax rate?


__answer__
commonFeedback:
1. Taxpayer A’s tax on ${{[a(9)]:#,###}} of income is computed as follows:
     
             
      {{[a(1)]:#,###}} % of first ${{[a(6)]:#,###}} of income $ {{[a(13)]:#,###}}  
      {{[a(2)]:#,###}} % of next ${{[a(11)]:#,###}} of income   {{[a(14)]:#,###}}  
      {{[a(3)]:#,###}} % of next ${{[a(12)]:#,###}} of income   {{[a(15)]:#,###}}  
            $ {{[a(16)]:#,###}}  


    Taxpayer A’s average tax rate is {{[a(17)]:#,###.00}}% (${{[a(16)]:#,###}} ÷ ${{[a(9)]:#,###}}), and his marginal tax rate is {{[a(3)]:#,###}}%.

  2. Taxpayer B’s tax on ${{[a(10)]:#,###}} of income is computed as follows:
     
             
      {{[a(1)]:#,###}} % of first ${{[a(6)]:#,###}} of income $ {{[a(13)]:#,###}}  
      {{[a(2)]:#,###}} % of next ${{[a(11)]:#,###}} of income   {{[a(14)]:#,###}}  
      {{[a(3)]:#,###}} % of next ${{[a(19)]:#,###}} of income   {{[a(21)]:#,###}}  
      {{[a(4)]:#,###}} % of next ${{[a(20)]:#,###}} of income   {{[a(22)]:#,###}}  
            $ {{[a(23)]:#,###}}  


    Taxpayer B’s average tax rate is {{[a(24)]:#,###.00}}% (${{[a(23)]:#,###}} ÷ ${{[a(10)]:#,###}}), and his marginal tax rate is {{[a(25)]:#,###}}%.

title: Learning Objective: 02-07 Explain the difference between marginal and average tax rates.
Topic: Marginal and Average Tax Rates

stem:
Government G levies an income tax with the following rate structure:
 

Percentage Rate Bracket
  6 % Income from –0– to $30,000
  10   Income from $30,001 to $70,000
  20   Income from $70,001 to $200,000
  28   Income in excess of $200,000
 
  1. Taxpayer A’s taxable income is $119,400. Compute A’s tax and average tax rate. What is A’s marginal tax rate?
  2. Taxpayer B’s taxable income is $383,900. Compute B’s tax and average tax rate. What is B’s marginal tax rate?


__answer__
commonFeedback:
1. Taxpayer A’s tax on $119,400 of income is computed as follows:
     
           
    6% of first $30,000 of income $ 1,800  
    10% of next $40,000 of income   4,000  
    20% of next $49,400 of income   9,880  
      $ 15,680  


    Taxpayer A’s average tax rate is 13.13% ($15,680 ÷ $119,400), and his marginal tax rate is 20%.

  2. Taxpayer B’s tax on $383,900 of income is computed as follows:
     
           
    6% of first $30,000 of income $ 1,800  
    10% of next $40,000 of income   4,000  
    20% of next $130,000 of income   26,000  
    28% of next $183,900 of income   51,492  
      $ 83,292  


    Taxpayer B’s average tax rate is 21.70% ($83,292 ÷ $383,900), and his marginal tax rate is 28%.

Thus, taxpayer O paid ${{[a(14)]:#,###}} tax for the {{[a(2)]:#,###}}-year period and had an average tax rate of {{[a(15)]:#,###.0}}% (${{[a(14)]:#,###}} ÷ ${{[a(12)]:#,###}}). Thus, taxpayer P paid ${{[a(18)]:#,###}} tax for the 10-year period and had an average tax rate of {{[a(19)]:#,###.0}}% (${{[a(18)]:#,###}} ÷ ${{[a(12)]:#,###}}).

title: Learning Objective: 02-05 Define horizontal and vertical equity.
Topic: Annual versus Lifetime Horizontal Equity

stem:
Government G levies an income tax with the following rate structure:
 

Percentage Rate Bracket
  6 % Income from –0– to $30,000
  10   Income from $30,001 to $70,000
  20   Income from $70,001 to $200,000
  28   Income in excess of $200,000


Taxpayer O earns $50,000 annually during years 1 through 10. Taxpayer P earns $20,000 annually during years 1 through 5 and $80,000 annually during years 6 through 10. Assume the tax rate bracket has not changed.

  1. How much total income does each taxpayer earn over the 10-year period?
  2. Compute each taxpayer’s average tax rate for the 10-year period.

 

__ans__
commonFeedback:
1. Both taxpayers earn $500,000 total income over the 10-year period.
  2. Taxpayer O paid an annual tax of $3,800 on $50,000 taxable income. Thus, taxpayer O paid $38,000 tax for the 10-year period and had an average tax rate of 7.6% ($38,000 ÷ $500,000). Taxpayer P paid an annual tax of $1,200 on $20,000 taxable income for years 1 through 5 and an annual tax of $7,800 on $80,000 taxable income for years 6 through 10. Thus, taxpayer P paid $45,000 tax for the 10-year period and had an average tax rate of 9% ($45,000 ÷ $500,000).

  1. Mr. Levi’s taxable income is $69,200. Compute his tax and average tax rate. What is Mr. Levi’s marginal tax rate?

In year 5, Ms. Ochoa’s wins a lottery, and her taxable income for this one year jumps to ${{[a(11)]:#,###}}. Assume the tax rate bracket has not changed.

title: Learning Objective: 02-07 Explain the difference between marginal and average tax rates.
Topic: Marginal and Average Tax Rates

stem:
Country A levies an individual income tax with the following rate structure:
 

Percentage Rate Bracket
  10 % Income from –0– to $20,000
  15   Income from $20,001 to $75,000
  25   Income from $75,001 to $160,000
  30   Income in excess of $160,000


Ms. Slattery’s annual taxable income for years 1 through 5 is $150,000. Ms. Ochoa’s taxable income for years 1 through 4 is $20,000. In year 5, Ms. Ochoa wins a lottery, and her taxable income for this one year jumps to $670,000. Assume the tax rate bracket has not changed.

  1. How much total income does each individual earn over the 5-year period?
  2. Compute each individual’s average tax rate for the 5-year period.
     

__ans__
commonFeedback:
1. Both taxpayers earn $750,000 total income over the 5-year period.
  2. Ms. Slattery paid $29,000 tax annually on $150,000 taxable income. Thus, Ms. Slattery paid $145,000 tax for the 5-year period and had an average tax rate of 19.33% ($145,000 ÷ $750,000). Ms. Ochoa paid $2,000 tax on $20,000 taxable income for years 1 through 4 and $184,500 tax on $670,000 taxable income for year 5. Thus, Ms. Ochoa paid $192,500 tax for the 5-year period and had an average tax rate of 25.67% ($192,500 ÷ $750,000).

title: Learning Objective: 02-06 Differentiate between regressive, proportionate, and progressive rate structures.
Learning Objective: 02-05 Define horizontal and vertical equity.
Topic: Annual versus Lifetime Horizontal Equity

stem:
Jurisdiction Z levies an excise tax on retail purchases of jewelry and watches. The tax equals {{[a(1)]:#,###}} percent of the first ${{[a(2)]:#,###}} of the purchase price plus {{[a(3)]:#,###}} percent of the purchase price in excess of ${{[a(4)]:#,###}}.
 

  1. Individual C purchases a watch for ${{[a(5)]:#,###}}. Compute C’s excise tax and average excise tax rate.
  2. Individual D purchases a watch for ${{[a(6)]:#,###}}. Compute D’s excise tax and average excise tax rate.
  3. Is Jurisdiction Z’s excise tax vertically equitable?


__ans__
commonFeedback:
1. Individual C’s excise tax is ${{[a(7)]:#,###.0}} and C’s average tax rate is {{[a(1)]:#,###.0}}% (${{[a(7)]:#,###.0}} ÷ ${{[a(5)]:#,###}}).
  2. Individual D’s excise tax is ${{[a(8)]:#,###.0}} and D’s average tax rate is {{[a(9)]:#,###.0}}% (${{[a(8)]:#,###.0}} ÷ ${{[a(6)]:#,###}}).
  3. Jurisdiction Z’s excise tax meets a strict definition of vertical equity because individual D, who has a larger tax base than individual C, pays more tax than individual C. However, the tax is regressive because individual D’s average tax rate is less than individual C’s average tax rate.

title: Learning Objective: 02-06 Differentiate between regressive, proportionate, and progressive rate structures.
Learning Objective: 02-05 Define horizontal and vertical equity.
Topic: Annual versus Lifetime Horizontal Equity

stem:
Jurisdiction Z levies an excise tax on retail purchases of jewelry and watches. The tax equals 3 percent of the first $1,000 of the purchase price plus 1 percent of the purchase price in excess of $1,000.
 

  1. Individual C purchases a watch for $500. Compute C’s excise tax and average excise tax rate.
  2. Individual D purchases a watch for $5,000. Compute D’s excise tax and average excise tax rate.
  3. Is Jurisdiction Z’s excise tax vertically equitable?


__ans__
commonFeedback:
1. Individual C’s excise tax is $15 and C’s average tax rate is 3% ($15 ÷ $500).
  2. Individual D’s excise tax is $70 and D’s average tax rate is 1.4% ($70 ÷ $5,000).
  3. Jurisdiction Z’s excise tax meets a strict definition of vertical equity because individual D, who has a larger tax base than individual C, pays more tax than individual C. However, the tax is regressive because individual D’s average tax rate is less than individual C’s average tax rate.
